instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-00163: What is 820-00163? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message:
Hello, 

I got this Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A came in with charging issue , I have founds a short   <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> , I proceeded to replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> AND <TRANSISTOR>Q7135</TRANSISTOR> As well as <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>  and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> to rule out the overall issue  then short was gone , but now i am having issues  , its only charging when screen is on , but as soon as it  goes to sleep mode , its not charging but the orange light is still present and also while the charger is plugged anytime we open a website or trying to do something , it would charge and cut off then restart charging again but as soon as it goes sleep mode it would not stop charging immediately . Can i get some ideas please ? 

Thank you

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message: What is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage, w/ and w/o battery connected?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message:
With Battery Connected i am getting 11.74V 

and without the battery connected  i am getting 18.74V

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is shorted, change it.
Be sure <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> is good.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message: Ok , I will go ahead and change it, but i had changed it too , so i will also change <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> and test it again .  <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> gets really hot too.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message: May need to change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> at same time...

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message: I changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> but the behavior is still the same as soon as computer goes to sleep it stopped charging, another thing is, it's asking for software update would that have anything to do with that as well , also <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> Was changed twice by good quality ones , should i change it again?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message:
"What is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage, w/ and w/o battery connected?"
Changing something without checking the effect, doesn't help...

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> With Battery connected 12.74 V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Without Battery Connected 18.74

So i am not seeing much changes. I don't have another good working board to compare those values , by any chance would you happen to have any charts of the correct value when everything is working properly? 

Please advice

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is shorted.
Do you see any other reason to have exact the same voltage on its input/output pins???

I don't know what you do there.
If <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is correctly soldered, or may have some broken trace.
Is not normal to get burnt, once changed with new/good one.
Check continuity from <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message: I can see that all the pads are normal and no broken traces I Wonder why it would do that too, I will see if i can get other <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> from other donors .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message: Did you check continuity from all <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> pads to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message: Yes , I did and yes there is continuity .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message:
Did you solder <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> correctly?
Shouldn't get burnt so easy, once replaced.
Unless broken trace to its pin 4, or <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Charging issue
threads.message: I did replace <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> , I think something from the inner layer .
